Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out, my phone buzzing with reminders. Management needed my project estimates by noon—no more delays, no more “I’ll get to it.” They were counting on me to be precise, to anchor the quarterly roadmap. My mind raced through calculations, weighing risks, trying to be both realistic and optimistic. Just as I was about to finalize my numbers, I remembered: today was voting day. I rushed to the polling station, laptop in my bag, estimates unfinished.

Inside, the poll worker handed me my ballot envelope. My signature had smudged. “Could you please re-sign?” she asked, her tone gentle but firm. I hesitated, glancing at the clock. The instructions were clear: follow every step, no shortcuts, or my vote might not count. But my phone vibrated again—another message from my manager, “Estimates?” I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. I wanted to do my civic duty right, but I also couldn’t let my team down. My hand hovered over the pen, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both demanded my full attention.
